story:
Short Summary

I am a poet and writer. My poetry has appeared, or is forthcoming, in Blackbird and The Innisfree Poetry Journal. My fiction was anthologized in Gumbo: An Anthology of African American Writing and has appeared in several journals and magazines, including Carve Magazine, African Voices, The Source, Bronx Biannual and 64 magazine. In 2003, WBEZ 91.5 FM, Chicago’s NPR affiliate, broadcast a dramatic reading of one of my stories as part of its Stories on Stage series. I have also written articles for a wide array of publications, including AlterNet, Guernica, The Source and Black Issues Book Review.

Recently, I won the 2012-2013 Eva Jane Romaine Coombe Writer’s Residency at The Seven Hills School, a pre-K — 12 private school in Cincinnati, Ohio. The yearlong residency is a great opportunity — it will give me the time I need to complete my first book of poems. The residency comes with a stipend and free housing and utilities. However, the stipend is modest; while it will cover my living expenses, it will not cover my additional expenses. This is why I am asking for your donation.

What I Need & What You Get

Let me give you a detailed picture of what the residency stipend will not cover. It will not cover the $2400 expense of having established poet and experienced teacher Matthew Lippman critique every poem that will go into the book (Lippman’s critique of my work in the last year or so helped me win the residency). Nor will the stipend cover relocation expenses. I will have to move from New York to Cincinnati before the 2012-2013 school year starts and will have to move again in July 2013, when the residency ends. Moving to Cincinnati will cost approximately $1750. Moving from Cincinnati in July 2013 will likely cost much more since — depending on employment, fellowship and graduate-school opportunities — I might not be able to return to New York. If I end up entering a PhD in Creative Writing program next fall, I might have to move as far away as Utah, LA or even Hawaii (Most of these programs are in the Midwest, West and Southwest). Moving to Utah would cost approximately $3000.

There are other expenses the stipend will not cover:

  • $2300: The cost of the four-week artist’s residency I won at the Vermont Studio Center. The residency will give me the time, space and inspiring environment I need to get a lot of writing done. The full cost of the residency is $3950, but the $1050 Artist’s Grant I won and the $600 Work Exchange Financial Aid Award I received brings the cost down to $2300. My residency will run from March 3 to March 29, 2013. (This month-long residency should not be confused with the yearlong Eva Jane Romaine Coombe Writer’s Residency I mentioned in paragraph 2.)
  • $1000: The fee for taking the GRE and the fees involved in applying to PhD in Creative Writing programs (Because the most selective programs have a very low acceptance rate [from 2% to 6%], I’ll apply to 12 programs).
  • $420: The cost of applying for fellowships, book awards (that grant book publication) and other writing awards.
  • $1675: The cost of attending the Association of Writers & Writing Programs (AWP) conference in Boston in March 2013 (The cost includes the registration fee, airfare, hotel accommodations, ground transportation and food). AWP is one of America’s largest and most influential literary communities. Attending the conference is vital to my success as a poet and writer.

The expenses I just listed come to a total of $12,545. My campaign goal is $3000, not nearly enough to fully cover my expenses. If I were to raise only that amount, I would have to exhaust my savings and borrow money. And yet $3000 would help a great deal. That said, it would be ideal if I received much more.

What You Get: See the Perks section to the right.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about this campaign through Facebook, Twitter, your blog, email, word of mouth, etc. Read my writing (go to www.danacrum.com/publications.html or google “Dana Crum”).

Thank you for your time.

story:
A Brief Intro: The A, B, C's

Hi, I'm Dave Burns.  I'm an Indie author located in Ottawa, KS (yeah - there's an Ottawa in Kansas).  I've always had a passion for writing, but have only been seriously writing since October of '09.  Since that time, I've got a few books under my belt (uncarvedbooks.com and amazon.com/author/daveburns).  


a) The Ottawa Writers' Guild

After I finished my first book (The Movement: A Children's Story for Grown-ups), I began looking around for creative writing groups that I could join to hone my craft.  Surprisingly, I really couldn't find any - not locally, anyway.  So I approached the Ottawa Library, and low and behold, several people had previously expressed interest.  There was even a file accumulated!  So I began contacting these individuals with the help of the Library Staff, and we began meeting March of '12.  

To date, The Ottawa Writers' Guild has over 20 members and 2 active groups.  The original group meets on the 1st and 3rd Saturdays of each month at the Library from 9am-Noon.  We originally met for 2 hours, but we had to up the time due to the increase of participants who wanted to share their work.  A good problem to have!  

Because of the large group size, another was created.  It meets at the Ottawa Community Arts Council (also called the Carnegie Cultural Center) twice a month, usually on Wednesday mornings (schedule varies due to availability).  

In an attempt to help bring about exposure for this group and other local authors/artists, I founded/created Uncarved: The Literature and Arts Magazine.  It's a compilation magazine of artistic mediums (written word, visual art, music, etc).  To date, we have 1 publication, which contained 15 different contributors with a total of 24 entries.  We hope to add more volumes as time goes on.

Testimonial

The Ottawa community has benefited greatly from the creation of the Ottawa Writers' Guild which a group of writers, poets and members who love literary works and the written word. Local author, Dave Burns, brought life to the Ottawa Writer’s Guild when he began organizing a group in March of this year that met twice a month at the Ottawa Library. The group inspires each other, bounces ideas off one another and is led by Dave Burns in writing instruction. The group wanted to publish their work online so they formed a guild and created a website blog. We put up a sign up sheet during summer reading for library patrons interested in learning to write or attending specific writing instruction or workshops, almost immediately 10 patrons signed up and each month the number doubles in interest. The response was so strong that Burns started up a second group that meets on Wednesdays at the Carnegie Cultural Center in Ottawa.  The Saturday Library group continues to meet twice a week and has an average of 8-10 participants each time.

Dave Burns has plans to increase his writing workshops and lessons and spread the love of writing more in the community. He wishes to lead more classes based in the Carnegie Cultural Center building, because of a lack of available funding the Ottawa Library wasn’t able to accommodate Burns in comprehensive writing instruction even though we realize there is a need and a hunger for this type of workshop in our community. We feel strongly that Burns’ writing classes are beneficial and we know they are well attended. His program would be a good thing to invest in it reaches many individuals in the community that may not be able to afford college writing classes or to travel far to neighboring cities.

Sincerely,

Lisa Slavin, Adult Programming at the Ottawa Library


b) The Creative Writing Program

I began putting the call out for interest in Creative Writing Classes and Workshops in May of '12 with the help of the Ottawa Library.  To date, over 50 people have signed up expressing interest.  And thanks to our blog (www.theottawawritersguild.wordpress.com) and my website (www.uncarvedbooks.com), we even have some individuals from Ottawa, Canada interested in classes.  Yet, another advantage of living in Ottawa, Kansas edition!

So far, we have had 4 different classes/workshops and 24 enrolled students.  Not bad for a start up, huh?  I have been researching and creating the curriculum, as well as taking suggestions for future classes from those enrolled.  As it stands, each 4-week class costs $40, and each 2-week workshop costs $30*. Each class runs approximately 2 hours, so a 4-week class has roughly 8 hours of instruction (as an example).  

Here's a list of classes/workshops that have been offered:

  • "The Nuts and Bolts of Creative Writing" - 4-week Class
  • "The Art of Creative Writing" - 4-week Class
  • "The Ins and outs of Self-Publishing" - 2-week Workshop
  • "Word Choice and Writing Tricks" - 2-week Workshop


And here are suggestions and classes/workshops on the horizon:

  • "Nice to Meet You. Now, Who Are You?" - Character Development and Dialogue
  • "Writing for the Future" - Planning a Career in Creative Writing (Teen Workshop)
  • "World Building"
  • "Memoirs and Family History"


Thanks in large part to our Northern Canadian Friends, we have even begun to research online classes, and hope to get that started in the near future.  

Testimonials

I took one of Dave's writing classes in November. I decided to take it because I am interested in pursuing a career that involves writing when I grow up. His class was even better than I expected.  It taught me a lot; especially that it's okay to make mistakes when you write. That was very important for me and took me a little while to grasp. I am very thankful that I took this class.

Perhaps the most important thing that Dave's class allowed me to do was to be able to have someone look at my writing. Before it had all been very private because I didn't want anyone judging it. Dave helped me through that and for that I am very grateful. Dave's writing class was super helpful. It encouraged me to continue thinking about a career with writing. I would recommend it to anyone who just loves to write.

Caroline Webber, age 12


*70% of class/workshop cost goes to pay the instructor (myself), and 30% goes to the Ottawa Community Arts Council.


c) Self-Publishing Consultant

In addition to staring both The Ottawa Writers' Guild and The Creative Writing Program, I have assisted 2 local authors in getting their work published.  I feel very strongly that everyone has a story to tell and should have the right to tell it, and I'm very proud of my involvement in helping make their dreams come true.  

Testimonial

Dave Burns was tremendously helpful and patient with me as I explored the world of self-publishing. His experience and expertise guided me through the process and his friendly encouragement gave me the confidence needed to complete the task. I look forward to working with him again in the near future!              

Beth McCluney, author of Snicklefritz and Buster the Horse


What We Need…

So, there's a ton of interest and a fair amount of involvement already, but this is just the tip of the iceberg.  So many more people would love to take Creative Writing Classes (as I've previously stated), but there's a catch… money.  Isn't it always money?

Here's the big and small of it: Ottawa is an underserved community with an estimated median household income of $41,000, and an unemployment rate of 7.5%.  Simply put: Not many people can afford classes.  I want to change that, and with your help, we can make it happen.

Here's my proposal.  I'm asking for $34,000.  What this money will do will fund my salary for 1 full year.  This will cover both groups of The Ottawa Writers' Guild, traditional Creative Writing Classes and Workshops, and Online Creative Writing Classes.  And this for all ages - children to adult.  This will also free me up to purchase 50 copies of Stephen King's amazing creative writing manual entitled On Writing, so every student can have their own personal copy.  Pretty awesome, right?  I thought so.  

$500 a month will go toward maintaining both groups (and any additional groups that spring up) of The Ottawa Writers' Guild.  This includes leading the groups, updating and facilitating the blog, scheduling meeting times, keeping up with new members, and acting as a liaison between the group(s) and the community.  This requires meetings and interactions with such organizations as the Ottawa Library, the Ottawa Community Arts Council, Greenbush (local adult education center), etc.  The funds will also go to continue creating and publishing Uncarved: The Literature and Arts Magazine, in an attempt to give the guild members further exposure for their work.  It will also make me more available to organize community events such as readings, book signings, etc.  In total, this will equate to $6,000 a year ($8,000 with income taxes included*).

$1,500 a month will go toward the paid instruction of the Creative Writing Classes and Workshops.  With these funds, I will be able to drastically reduce the cost of student fees.  All 2-week workshops will now only cost $10 per student, and 4-week classes will be $15.  While any 8-week classes will only cost $20 per student.  And all of these funds would go directly to the Ottawa Community Arts Council!  This is a Triple-Win!!! These funds will also go toward helping other local authors get self-published at no additional cost.  I'll be able to offer my consulting services for free to those in The Ottawa Writers' Guild and The Creative Writing Program.  In total, this will equate to $18,000 a year ($24,000 with income taxes included*).

In addition, there are some one-time costs to getting everything set up.  I'm asking for $1,000 to purchase a laptop with a webcam and the appropriate equipment in order to conduct online classes.  This will be available to everyone, and like I said, we already have people waiting in the wings to get started.

Also, an additional $500 will go toward purchasing 50 copies of Stephen King's On Writing (as previously mentioned).  If we need more, we can buy more at a later time.  But this will certainly get us going in the right direction.  Both of these one-time purchases equate to $1,500 once ($2,000 with income taxes included*).

So here’s the breakdown:

  • Ottawa Writers' Guild @ $500/month

$6,000/year ($8,000 w/Tax)

  • Creative Writing Program @ $1500/month

$18,000/year ($24,000 w/Tax)

  • Equipment

$1000/once - laptop w/webcam for online classes

$500/once - 50 copies of Stephen King's On Writing @ $10/piece

$1,500/once ($2000 w/Tax)

  • $27,500 Grand Total ($34,000 w/Tax)

$34,000 Total Funding Needed (25% Income Tax Included)


*Yes, I have to pay income taxes on this.  : (

Or

If somehow we raise $40,000, it gets even better!  Everything from above applies except there would be NO STUDENT COSTS!!!  In addition to that, $4,500 will go directly to the Ottawa Community Arts Council ($1,500 set aside for income tax*)!!!  An even bigger Triple-Win!!!

If we don't reach our minimum goal of $34,000, some things will obviously have to change.  The first thing to go will be the copies of On Writing for the students, followed by the computer and equipment for online classes.  Depending on what is raised, I may not be able to offer as many Creative Writing Classes/Workshops as there is interest for, nor create additional writing groups if the need arises.    

So please, let's make this happen!

Testimonial

Dave Burns and his creative writing program have been such an incredible asset to the Ottawa Community Arts Council's programming.  He has not only provided an opportunity for members of our community to come together and express themselves creatively, but he has also filled a need for encouraging continued literacy in our small town.  His enthusiasm and determination have been the key in his program's success.  We at the Arts Council are very excited to work with Mr. Burns and we look forward to many
more great opportunities with him in the future as his program builds.

Sincerely,

Stephanie Williamson
Gallery and Educational Director of the Ottawa Community Arts Council


…And What You Get

PERKS!!!

I've started contributions beginning as low as $1, so hopefully everyone can get involved!

What does $1 get you?  A virtual 'Thank You!' - a personalized email from me, as well as my undying gratitude!

$25?  Social Media Slam!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: An opportunity to post your work on The Ottawa Writers' Guild blog with a comment and/or review by me.  In addition, you get a Twitter and Facebook 'Shout Out!' with a link to your blog/website/etc!

$50? Write and Inspire!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: 1 private 2 hour Creative Writing Class or your choice, either online or in person!

$100? Be Immortalized in Ink!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: I'll write a personalized short story for you!

$250? Join the eBook Revolution!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: I'll help you publish your eBook!

$500? Become a Paperback Writer!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: I'll help you publish your paperback!

You're All In!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: Congratulations!  Free Creative Writing Classes/Workshops for the life of the program!  Also you'll get a free signed paperback copy of one of my books: The Movement: A Children's Story for Grown-ups, The Movement: Concluded, or Pieces of Me!

A Brief Intro: The A, B, C'sHi, I'm Dave Burns.  I'm an Indie author located in Ottawa, KS (yeah - there's an Ottawa in Kansas).  I've always had a passion for writing, but have only been seriously writing since October of '09.  Since that time, I've got a few books under my belt (uncarvedbooks.com and amazon.com/author/daveburns).  a) The Ottawa Writers' GuildAfter I finished my first book (The Movement: A Children's Story for Grown-ups), I began looking around for creative writing groups that I could join to hone my craft.  Surprisingly, I really couldn't find any - not locally, anyway.  So I approached the Ottawa Library, and low and behold, several people had previously expressed interest.  There was even a file accumulated!  So I began contacting these individuals with the help of the Library Staff, and we began meeting March of '12.  To date, The Ottawa Writers' Guild has over 20 members and 2 active groups.  The original group meets on the 1st and 3rd Saturdays of each month at the Library from 9am-Noon.  We originally met for 2 hours, but we had to up the time due to the increase of participants who wanted to share their work.  A good problem to have!  Because of the large group size, another was created.  It meets at the Ottawa Community Arts Council (also called the Carnegie Cultural Center) twice a month, usually on Wednesday mornings (schedule varies due to availability).  In an attempt to help bring about exposure for this group and other local authors/artists, I founded/created Uncarved: The Literature and Arts Magazine.  It's a compilation magazine of artistic mediums (written word, visual art, music, etc).  To date, we have 1 publication, which contained 15 different contributors with a total of 24 entries.  We hope to add more volumes as time goes on.TestimonialThe Ottawa community has benefited greatly from the creation of the Ottawa Writers' Guild which a group of writers, poets and members who love literary works and the written word. Local author, Dave Burns, brought life to the Ottawa Writer’s Guild when he began organizing a group in March of this year that met twice a month at the Ottawa Library. The group inspires each other, bounces ideas off one another and is led by Dave Burns in writing instruction. The group wanted to publish their work online so they formed a guild and created a website blog. We put up a sign up sheet during summer reading for library patrons interested in learning to write or attending specific writing instruction or workshops, almost immediately 10 patrons signed up and each month the number doubles in interest. The response was so strong that Burns started up a second group that meets on Wednesdays at the Carnegie Cultural Center in Ottawa.  The Saturday Library group continues to meet twice a week and has an average of 8-10 participants each time.Dave Burns has plans to increase his writing workshops and lessons and spread the love of writing more in the community. He wishes to lead more classes based in the Carnegie Cultural Center building, because of a lack of available funding the Ottawa Library wasn’t able to accommodate Burns in comprehensive writing instruction even though we realize there is a need and a hunger for this type of workshop in our community. We feel strongly that Burns’ writing classes are beneficial and we know they are well attended. His program would be a good thing to invest in it reaches many individuals in the community that may not be able to afford college writing classes or to travel far to neighboring cities.Sincerely,Lisa Slavin, Adult Programming at the Ottawa Libraryb) The Creative Writing ProgramI began putting the call out for interest in Creative Writing Classes and Workshops in May of '12 with the help of the Ottawa Library.  To date, over 50 people have signed up expressing interest.  And thanks to our blog (www.theottawawritersguild.wordpress.com) and my website (www.uncarvedbooks.com), we even have some individuals from Ottawa, Canada interested in classes.  Yet, another advantage of living in Ottawa, Kansas edition!So far, we have had 4 different classes/workshops and 24 enrolled students.  Not bad for a start up, huh?  I have been researching and creating the curriculum, as well as taking suggestions for future classes from those enrolled.  As it stands, each 4-week class costs $40, and each 2-week workshop costs $30*. Each class runs approximately 2 hours, so a 4-week class has roughly 8 hours of instruction (as an example).  Here's a list of classes/workshops that have been offered:

"The Nuts and Bolts of Creative Writing" - 4-week Class
"The Art of Creative Writing" - 4-week Class
"The Ins and outs of Self-Publishing" - 2-week Workshop
"Word Choice and Writing Tricks" - 2-week Workshop
And here are suggestions and classes/workshops on the horizon:

"Nice to Meet You. Now, Who Are You?" - Character Development and Dialogue
"Writing for the Future" - Planning a Career in Creative Writing (Teen Workshop)
"World Building"
"Memoirs and Family History"
Thanks in large part to our Northern Canadian Friends, we have even begun to research online classes, and hope to get that started in the near future.  TestimonialsI took one of Dave's writing classes in November. I decided to take it because I am interested in pursuing a career that involves writing when I grow up. His class was even better than I expected.  It taught me a lot; especially that it's okay to make mistakes when you write. That was very important for me and took me a little while to grasp. I am very thankful that I took this class.Perhaps the most important thing that Dave's class allowed me to do was to be able to have someone look at my writing. Before it had all been very private because I didn't want anyone judging it. Dave helped me through that and for that I am very grateful. Dave's writing class was super helpful. It encouraged me to continue thinking about a career with writing. I would recommend it to anyone who just loves to write.Caroline Webber, age 12*70% of class/workshop cost goes to pay the instructor (myself), and 30% goes to the Ottawa Community Arts Council.c) Self-Publishing ConsultantIn addition to staring both The Ottawa Writers' Guild and The Creative Writing Program, I have assisted 2 local authors in getting their work published.  I feel very strongly that everyone has a story to tell and should have the right to tell it, and I'm very proud of my involvement in helping make their dreams come true.  TestimonialDave Burns was tremendously helpful and patient with me as I explored the world of self-publishing. His experience and expertise guided me through the process and his friendly encouragement gave me the confidence needed to complete the task. I look forward to working with him again in the near future!              Beth McCluney, author of Snicklefritz and Buster the HorseWhat We Need…So, there's a ton of interest and a fair amount of involvement already, but this is just the tip of the iceberg.  So many more people would love to take Creative Writing Classes (as I've previously stated), but there's a catch… money.  Isn't it always money?Here's the big and small of it: Ottawa is an underserved community with an estimated median household income of $41,000, and an unemployment rate of 7.5%.  Simply put: Not many people can afford classes.  I want to change that, and with your help, we can make it happen.Here's my proposal.  I'm asking for $34,000.  What this money will do will fund my salary for 1 full year.  This will cover both groups of The Ottawa Writers' Guild, traditional Creative Writing Classes and Workshops, and Online Creative Writing Classes.  And this for all ages - children to adult.  This will also free me up to purchase 50 copies of Stephen King's amazing creative writing manual entitled On Writing, so every student can have their own personal copy.  Pretty awesome, right?  I thought so.  $500 a month will go toward maintaining both groups (and any additional groups that spring up) of The Ottawa Writers' Guild.  This includes leading the groups, updating and facilitating the blog, scheduling meeting times, keeping up with new members, and acting as a liaison between the group(s) and the community.  This requires meetings and interactions with such organizations as the Ottawa Library, the Ottawa Community Arts Council, Greenbush (local adult education center), etc.  The funds will also go to continue creating and publishing Uncarved: The Literature and Arts Magazine, in an attempt to give the guild members further exposure for their work.  It will also make me more available to organize community events such as readings, book signings, etc.  In total, this will equate to $6,000 a year ($8,000 with income taxes included*). $1,500 a month will go toward the paid instruction of the Creative Writing Classes and Workshops.  With these funds, I will be able to drastically reduce the cost of student fees.  All 2-week workshops will now only cost $10 per student, and 4-week classes will be $15.  While any 8-week classes will only cost $20 per student.  And all of these funds would go directly to the Ottawa Community Arts Council!  This is a Triple-Win!!! These funds will also go toward helping other local authors get self-published at no additional cost.  I'll be able to offer my consulting services for free to those in The Ottawa Writers' Guild and The Creative Writing Program.  In total, this will equate to $18,000 a year ($24,000 with income taxes included*).In addition, there are some one-time costs to getting everything set up.  I'm asking for $1,000 to purchase a laptop with a webcam and the appropriate equipment in order to conduct online classes.  This will be available to everyone, and like I said, we already have people waiting in the wings to get started.Also, an additional $500 will go toward purchasing 50 copies of Stephen King's On Writing (as previously mentioned).  If we need more, we can buy more at a later time.  But this will certainly get us going in the right direction.  Both of these one-time purchases equate to $1,500 once ($2,000 with income taxes included*).So here’s the breakdown:

Ottawa Writers' Guild @ $500/month
$6,000/year ($8,000 w/Tax)

Creative Writing Program @ $1500/month
$18,000/year ($24,000 w/Tax)

Equipment
$1000/once - laptop w/webcam for online classes
$500/once - 50 copies of Stephen King's On Writing @ $10/piece
$1,500/once ($2000 w/Tax)

$27,500 Grand Total ($34,000 w/Tax)
$34,000 Total Funding Needed (25% Income Tax Included)
*Yes, I have to pay income taxes on this.  : (OrIf somehow we raise $40,000, it gets even better!  Everything from above applies except there would be NO STUDENT COSTS!!!  In addition to that, $4,500 will go directly to the Ottawa Community Arts Council ($1,500 set aside for income tax*)!!!  An even bigger Triple-Win!!!If we don't reach our minimum goal of $34,000, some things will obviously have to change.  The first thing to go will be the copies of On Writing for the students, followed by the computer and equipment for online classes.  Depending on what is raised, I may not be able to offer as many Creative Writing Classes/Workshops as there is interest for, nor create additional writing groups if the need arises.    So please, let's make this happen!TestimonialDave Burns and his creative writing program have been such an incredible asset to the Ottawa Community Arts Council's programming.  He has not only provided an opportunity for members of our community to come together and express themselves creatively, but he has also filled a need for encouraging continued literacy in our small town.  His enthusiasm and determination have been the key in his program's success.  We at the Arts Council are very excited to work with Mr. Burns and we look forward to many more great opportunities with him in the future as his program builds.Sincerely,Stephanie WilliamsonGallery and Educational Director of the Ottawa Community Arts Council…And What You GetPERKS!!!I've started contributions beginning as low as $1, so hopefully everyone can get involved!What does $1 get you?  A virtual 'Thank You!' - a personalized email from me, as well as my undying gratitude!$25?  Social Media Slam!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: An opportunity to post your work on The Ottawa Writers' Guild blog with a comment and/or review by me.  In addition, you get a Twitter and Facebook 'Shout Out!' with a link to your blog/website/etc!$50? Write and Inspire!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: 1 private 2 hour Creative Writing Class or your choice, either online or in person!$100? Be Immortalized in Ink!  You get everything listed above, PLUS: I'll write a personalized short story for you!$250? story:
We Still Like’s 2010 Subscription Drive

We’re tired of hearing that literature is dead. We are so tired, in fact, we started a literary zine called We Still Like. Why would anyone start such an endeavor in this day and age? Simple: We Still Like Books!

We still believe in the power of language and the importance of sincerity. We still believe that literature is as vital as oxygen, that it keeps us human and lets us forge real connections. We are tired of cowering behind a shield of irony and taking ourselves oh-so-seriously because we’re told that’s what writers are supposed to do. Creation and connection shouldn’t have to be so hard. We need your help to save literature.

We still like saying something true, creating sincere work distinct from the tides of commerce. But when language has been cheapened and sentiment discredited, sincerity becomes a radical concept. Speaking in a bright, clear voice becomes an act of revolution.

We still see this as literature’s purpose. It’s been our mantra ever since we published the first issue of We Still Like in a handmade limited edition of 100 — not too fussed over, not too perfect, but printed, stacked, bound, loved and sent out into the tangible world. And the response has been overwhelming. We’ve already sold out of the first issue and begun to cultivate a community passionate about contributing to the cause by hosting readings and distributing We Still Like at local bookshops.

Now that we’ve proven it can be done, we want to keep doing it. We’re poised to release our second issue: We Still Like Gravity, a collection of investigations into all that is weighty and meaningful, all that is too big and too small to take, all that pulls us together and all that makes us light. It features a special screenprinted cover and work by some of our very favorite writers. You can see what we’ve been up to and read selections from We Still Like at http://WeStillLike.blogspot.com/.

We see We Still Like as the bridge between our authors and an audience who is likewise tired of suffering the status quo, who wants more than hollow work overhyped, who wants access to the meaningful creations of hard-working artists who so often go undervalued.

Our donors are the trestles of this bridge. We Still Like has no external funding, but instead relies directly on you for its survival — you finding it interesting, inspiring and, most importantly, valuable enough to keep it alive and growing. Initial sales and donations defrayed some of the printing costs of the first issue. With the help of new readers and your continued support, we are excited to make each successive issue more ambitious and sustainable.

We Still Like Philanthropy! Our current goal covers our operating costs for this issue cycle (see details, right), ensuring you get your hands on the current and next We Still Like. By helping our 2010 subscription drive succeed, you’ll be making sure literature and sincerity live to fight another day. In a world gone digital, we still like books — and we want to keep making them so you can keep reading them.

story:
Help Free Sylvia Plath - We Want to Publish Her Debut Collection in Germany


Sylvia Plath's work has been translated in many languages. In Germany - one of the biggest bookmarkets in Europe - the only poetry book available by her is "Ariel" and - oddly enough - a selection of "Love Poems". 


We want to publish the exceptional translation of her debut collection "The Colossus and Other Poems" translated by one of Germany's acclaimed young poets Judith Zander. We sincerely believe that the debut collection by one of the most influential American poets of her generation should be available to German readers in a bilingual edition. The German publisher of "Ariel" and "The Bell Jar" seems to be blocking all rights to the book by an option right they don't use - needless to say that they have never published an edition of "The Colossus" and it seems unclear what their plans for the future are. 


We are a small Independent Publisher called luxbooks focusing on American poetry in bilingual editions. Among our authors are John Ashbery, Rae Armantrout, Mary Jo Bang, Hart Crane, H.D., Timothy Donnelly, Forrest Gander, Peter Gizzi, Ben Lerner, Sarah Manguso, George Oppen, D. A. Powell and John Updike. The translations are normally done by acclaimed German poets. Our books are regularly reviewed in national newspapers, radio and television. The leading Swiss Newspaper NZZ called us the "currently most influential Independent Poetry publisher in Germany". We can't however compete with a big publishing house on our own. We figure that we have to raise at least 6.000$ to be able to make a competitive offer.


Luxbooks is being run by us: Annette KÃ¼hn (*1981) & Christian Lux (*1978), two poetry loving Independent publishers from Wiesbaden. There are many portraits about our publishing house in German media (FAZ, Deutschlandfunk, NZZ, Frankfurter Rundschau, BÃ¶rsenblatt des Deutschen Buchhandels, Buchmarkt) and many more reviews of our books. This is our website: www.luxbooks.de



(Photo (c) Frankfurter Rundschau)


Judith Zander (*1980), the translator of the book, is one of the most acclaimed young poets in Germany. Born in Anklam, she studied German, English and History in Greifswald and Creative Writing in Leipzig. Her poetry and prose has won many awards: among them are a nomination for Germany's Most important Book Award, the DBP, the prestigious 3sat-Preis awarded during the Ingeborg Bachmann-Preis and the Wolfang-Weyrauch-FÃ¶rderpreis. 



(Photo (c) Amrei-Marie)


What Happens If You Raise More Money Than You Need to Free Sylvia Plath


If we raise more money than necessary we will also:

 

1. - try to buy the German rights for "Crossing the Water" the last collection by Sylvia Plath (ca. 5000$)

2. - pay translation costs (ca. 2500$)

3. - pay printing and advertising costs for the book (ca. 3000$)

4. - distribute free copies of the edition to libraries 


If you decide to still donate to the project when all theses costs are covered we will use any additional money for our series luxbooks.americana in which the Sylvia Plath edition will be published. Planned future projects are f.ex. selected poetry editions by Frank O'Hara, John Berryman, John Ashbery, Charles Bernstein, Lyn Hejinian.


What Happens If We Don't Get the Rights?


If we are not able to aquire the rights, we will use half of the donations to pay a translation fee to Judith Zander as her translation will remain unpublished then. We will donate the other half to the Pennsound-Archive, a web archive of preserved readings and audio documents from 20th century poets.


Why Freeing Sylvia Plath's Debut Collection in Germany Is Important


"The Colossus and Other Poems" established Sylvia Plath as a major poet long before her now famous suicide. She is one of the leading poets of confessional poetry, her work is part of the American poetry canon, her life and work was influential on many leading feminists of the second half of the 20th century and she has become one of the few true icons of literature. 


For the first time our edition would make it possible to read Sylvia Plath's debut collection in German. As we always publish bilingual editions the reader will have the possibilty to compare the translation to the original. As it will have taken more than 50 years until a German translation has been published, the book will be met with anticipation and earn many reviews. Many new readers and a generation of young poets will be able to discover Sylvia Plath's early work.


If we can't succed in freeing Sylvia Plath's debut collection from the bigger publishing house this essential poetry book will remain unknown to German readers and Judith Zander's marvelous translation won't be published.


You Want to Help Us Free Sylvia? 


We need support for our cause. As the British publishing house which owns the rights has a longstanding relationship to the German publishing house which seems to be blocking the rights we probably not only need money but also public backing for our demand to make "The Colossus" available to German readers. Please make this campaign known to your friends, fellow readers and to the media. 


We need at least 5,000$ to compete with any offer the German publishing house might make.


You will get to be part of a campaign trying to end copyright abuse. You will be part of those who want to "Free Sylvia Plath". For any donation above 50â‚¬ you will get a "Free-Sylvia-Plath-T-Shirt".

For any donation above 100â‚¬ you will get a copy of the final book if we can aquire the rights. Any donation above 500â‚¬ will be mentioned in the "Thank You"-note of the final book.


You Don't Need to Donate Money to Help Free Sylvia Plath:

Please let your friends know. Engage with the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube or whereever you spend your social media hours!


http://www.facebook.com/freesylviaplath 

http://twitter.com/#!/freesylviaplath

http://www.youtube.com/FreeSylviaPlath

story:
20 years ago, a shy autistic man who had never written more then a shopping list and had failed English at school, met a literary agent. She was so impressed with his turn of phrase and beautiful storytelling style that she asked him to write her 8 chapters of a novel.

Not realising it was ‘supposed’ to be hard to write a book, he did just that – handing those first chapters over to her only three weeks later…

 

That man was Caiseal Mór. Within three weeks of publication his first novel ‘The Circle and the Cross’ was a best seller. Caiseal was the first Australian author to have their first book signed up to a deal on an unfinished manuscript.

 

In the ensuing years Caiseal published another 16 books, and also 14 music CDs.  He has travelled and had many adventures, but now on the eve of the 20th anniversary of his first book he has decided it's time to do something to honour those stories that have touched so many people over the years.

We are going to re-release the books as ebooks. But not only that, Caiseal plans to expand them, to re-introduce the more magical elements the editors of the conservative publishing houses made him take out in the original printed versions. For the first time you will get to see and read Caiseal’s novels as he intended them to be.

This campaign is to raise the funds to convert the books (which the original word documents have been lost) into digital form from hard copy. This indiegogo campaign is for the first three books (the Wanderers Trilogy) Being: The Circle and the Cross; The Song of the Earth; The Water of Life.

If this project proves successful we will be launching future campaigns with the vision of eventually having all 15 books of his (those which are not currently available as ebooks) to be also expanded and re-released as ebooks.

Getting excited with the potential of expanded versions of these three books, we have also decided to print a limited edition, signed box set of the trilogy for those bibliophiles out there who need to have beautiful hard copies of their most loved stories to fondle and admire. So the funds raised in this campaign will also pay for the printing of those books.

 

Caiseal often receives requests for digital versions of his novels, so we hope many people will be delighted to support this project - a project quite a lot of you have suggested is long overdue.

 Caiseal will also create all new artwork for the covers.

For those of you who have yet to read any of Caiseal’s novels, please scroll down to the bottom of this window to enjoy the prologue of ‘The Circle and the Cross’ and please help us by sharing this campaign whereever you can.

Thank-you,

Helen Wells (Caiseal’s manager and life partner)

June 2013.

 

The Circle and the Cross

Caiseal Mór

Prologue:

 

 

Hear the wind wailing down a chimney on the darkest night of winter. Sit at the fire warming flesh that has blued in icy air. Rest eyes that ache, feet that are weary. Listen to the homely sounds of neighbours preparing meals in cottages nearby.      

Imagine, if you will, a dry-stone dwelling that is empty save for the silent long dead souls who keep watch over the house. Across a cobbled courtyard spring water struggles up through stone pipes into a granite trough worn smooth in the great passage of years once the first Gaels set in there.

Snow lies heavy on thatch. Ice hugs doorsteps. Golden lamplight escapes from cracks in wooden window shutters. Sweet peat smoke scents a chill breeze that enfolds the tiny settlement, gathering sounds and lifting them into the night.

An old song-maker, chanting in the style of her ancestors, raises a keening cry lamenting the long absence of summer. The hills around hear the notes and pass them down the valley, adding the muffled tunes of their kind. They remember other winters and other races who have long since left this place to pass eternity in Tir-Nan-Og, the land of the everliving.

Here, amongst these folk who called themselves the Feni, was I born and there passed my first years on this Earth.

A traveller chanced by that place some ten years ago. He told me what he saw. The houses are now ruined shells. The timber is rotted and the hearthstones lie cold. The people are all gone. They live only in my memory.

I have not, in all this time since, returned to the valley of my ancestors. Now I am too old and the journey is too dangerous. I can only dream that I am home and hope that my yearning heart will be satisfied one day.

Oh, but when I dream it is not always of winter’s bite. I dream also of the clear air at summertime. I dream of the ordinary daily tasks that everyone in the clan hold had duty to share.

And there is one scene that unfolds itself in sleep-travel time and again. A child is dutifully chasing the goats at sunset to bring them in to the safety of their enclosure. He has yellow hair and a soft, easy laugh. He is slender and his eyes are deep-set and dark-ringed. He knows each goat by name and one or two he addresses as equals. From them he has learned his first lessons in respect.

His feet follow a hoof-beaten dirt track down the side of a small grass-covered knoll toward the round hillfort that his people call the dun. The goats march before him, breaking into a trot at the sight of their home, knowing the shelter and water await them there.

The boy does not notice the farmers or labourers of even the people of his own clan working within the low walls. He does not smell the supper boiling at the cooking fire. He cannot hear the greetings of his friends or the gentle rebukes of his mother.

His head is full of the words of the storytellers.

In private delight, he brings to mind every expression, every gesture that he has witnessed, striving to recall all he can of the old tales. He is truly a dreamer. He would leave his home tomorrow now, if he could, to be a poet.

That young dreamer still lives strong in me.

But surely I am speaking to you of some things a little too soon. There will be time enough for that part of the story later.

This tale really begins at the far end of the same valley where a trickling stream narrowed before pouring into a pool. At that place, a roughly-built rock ford reached the sand on the other side of the water. And there, almost smothered by blackthorn bushes, lay the beginnings of a road.

This was no ordinary road. To me and my clan, this was the Road.

It was our link to the world beyond. It was our lifeline, our protector, our procurer of rare goods. We revered the Road for, you see, we lived at one of those rare places where it came to an end.

In these times there are few people living who could tell you more than rumours whispered and half-truths of the origins and history of the Road. I alone remain of those who ever knew the larger part of the tale.

Beyond our valley, towns and cities and palaces and empires erupted like springtime seedlings from the edges of the Road. The taverns groaned full of travellers who wandered it; the markets hummed as its side just as the hives of worker bees buzzed in their all-consuming labour.

            This Road brought all together: the farmer, the soldier, the journeyman, the merchant, the priest, the kind, the lowly beggar. The Road served all, yet mastered each, for it drew travellers then as I imagine it draws folk still, spurring their curiosity to set out for the lands that lie beyond the well-worn comfort of familiarity.

            Would that you ever find yourself walking the Road, trudging without purpose, seeking some journey’s end, I give you this warning. The Road is a living being. She is an enchantress and She has a long reach.

            She may at her whim lead you to the edge of the world, into the lands of light. Aye, and She could as well set you on the paths that reach only into the darkest corners of this Earth.

            The Road holds within Her an unseen current that will drag you to Her holiest shrines. There She will reveal her mighty triumphs, each greater than the last, each a song of Her splendour. In that moment when you are caught up by the travel-trance, you will become lost to all your fellow beings, though you may well be surrounded by them.

            For my part, there have been times, many times, when the will to continue on the long Road almost deserted me. There came a day, once, when my body lay battered, exhausted and near-dead and my soul yearned for the quiet respite of the lands beyond life. In all that suffering my only constant companion was the Road. It was She alone who could carry me forward to a safe-haven or to disaster, as was Her whim.

            These days I rest often and travel little. I have a room in a town, in a country far from my homeland. In this time I have no leisure to journey, but the spirit of the Road still returns to taunt me. She fills my mind with part-recollected, part-imagined scenes from my wanderings, dangling before me enticing visions of what might have been or what yet may be.

            Last night She came to me in my room as I sat strumming the harp before the fire. Yester’s eve marked the time of the Great Festival that my people called Beltinne or the Fires of Bel. The folk of this country celebrate that feast in a different manner from the tribes of Eirinn. Here the people mill around the market cross and sing and dance and when they are too tired or too drunk they return home to their beds.

            As the sounds of their merrymaking drifted in through my window, I wandered into the realm of soul-flight.  I lifted up, leaving my body behind, and sailed high up over the stone-tiled town only to float gently down again in the midst of the thronging crowds. There before me a small drama unfolded.

A child’s toy boat was swept along by the gutter-stream. Faster and faster it sailed until the heart-broken youngster could keep up no longer and was left crying in vain for his tiny craft. The cleverly carved treasure disappeared in the swirling whirlpool of a sewer grate, ever bobbing along toward the river, out of the sight and knowledge of mortals. My mind’s eye observed what happened after.

The building torrent of the flood carried the fragile ship out to meet the lapping waters of the blue depths. Far, far, ever seaward, sailed the toy. Through storms and calm it voyaged to be washed up by the tide one morning in another country where a child, not unlike the fellow who mourned its loss, found the boat, admired the workmanship, cherished the possession of it, but never guessed how long it had travelled nor whence it came.

In that vision rests the mystery of the true nature of the Road. Lost wanderers such as myself are like unto that toy boat lifted up on the wave crests of the Ocean of Being to glimpse at distant harbours from dizzy heights, only to be plunged down once more into the swell of the surging salt water before the eyes can fully focus on the horizon.

As the years continue to unfold, these trance-journeys come often to replace my clear memories of the old days. So many names and faces are lost now forever in the murky oblivion of forgetfulness. Yet I remember now, and will remember beyond this life, the dream-tales that first led me on my quests. I will remember the storytellers and their harps. I will remember the man who first spoke to me of the Road and I will remember our first meeting and our long friendship.

I will remember also the cherished gift he gave at my initiation. The gift of a name.

I am called Mawn.

story:
Palestinian Women's Voices

“In life and life’s demands, we find that a woman can live with or without a man.  She can do all the things that a man does and more - working and taking care of the household. Today’s woman has two roles: she brings in money like a man, and makes decisions like a man.  The ‘soldier’ way of life is no longer lived inside the house.  There are only soldiers outside," says Noura (27 year old who holds a Master's degree, works for a media company and lives with her husband and two kids in Ramallah).

“Religion is not the most important thing in life. It’s not about duty, it is what  calls you from within. Prayer can be a very personal thing, without showing that you’re doing it in front of the world.  But some people are afraid and they enforce hijab. If you don’t fear God then why fear people? If you are a good Muslim, then there is no reason to fear people”  (Samira, 19 year old newlywed, first year Birzeit University student).

“When I used to go to school in the ‘60s, you didn’t see a woman go to college.  I remember one girl who went to a private school. Women my mom’s age did not go to school.   They received zero education...more like ‘zero minus’. Marriage was more important and parents may not have been able to buy notebooks and books to send their kids to school. Villages only offered education to a certain level (4th, 5th, 6th grade) and if you wanted a higher education, you had to send your kids to a city like Ramallah or Al-Bireh. Back then transportation cost the equivalent of 5 cents  from Beitin to Ramallah.   Men could  not  afford  to  send  all  their  kids to  the  city every  day. Women did not traditionally leave the house so it was hard for them to let their daughters travel alone to  a  city.  There was also no point in sending girls to school because there were no  jobs that supported women in the marketplace.  It was shameful for women to work outside the house.  But that rendered women hopeless in trying to take care of themselves when their husbands divorced them or died..." (Yasmine, 71 year old mother of 8 children, completed 8th grade).

Story & Background

This book is a reflection of 55 face-to-face interviews with Palestinian women ages 18-90, living in the West Bank.  It is my belief that, in the West, we normally do not hear about Palestinian women except in the context of religious oppression, domestic abuse or war.  I wanted to have a better understanding of how Palestinian women perceive themselves, the societies they live in, and the West.  This project is unique as it provides a first hand account of Palestinian women's thoughts, feelings and beliefs.  This book also serves as a platform to anyone interested in learning, "Who is a Palestinian woman?"

This research was originally my Master's thesis, "The Evolution of a Palestinian Woman, from 1940 until Now" and it is in the process of being edited into a book.

Interview questions include:
1.  What is the role of a Palestinian woman in society?

2.  Is it important to have a man in your life?

3.  What are the biggest challenges facing Palestinian women your age?

4.  What are similarities or differences between American and Palestinian women?

5.  Which women served as your role models growing up?

The Need

The money raised will go towards a book cover design, final edits, and translations in Arabic and Spanish.

Other Ways to Support

If you're unable to contribute financially, please spread the word via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, etc. to others who may be interested or able to contribute. Please help me make the most of this opportunity. Thank you :)

Contact Me Directly

T: +(615) 405-1488 mobile

E: sadiqua.hamdan@gmail.com

story:
I have been writing and drawing for as long as I can remember and it has always been a dream of mine to write and illustrate a children's book.
 
 
Alpha Betty Soup started as a series of drawings of my daughter, Marley. Being 5 years old (at the time), she was very interested in the letters of the alphabet and was beginning to learn to read, so an ABC book was a natural choice for me, as her mom.
 

I had lots of fun writing all of the silly, rhyming verses of the book and drawing the matching illustrations for each letter of the alphabet. I really enjoyed seeing the delight on my daughter's face as I developed the Betty character and took her on this giggly journey through the ABCs.
 
The book is now completed and available as an ebook on Kobo, Amazon and iTunes. But my true vision for Alpha Betty Soup has always been to turn it into an interactive mobile application with sound effects, read along capabilities, animations and music. But alas, in order to add these features, I need help from other talented geeks like myself.
 
So that brings us to my campaign.
 

 

Up until this point, my book has been completely self-funded.
I do, however, need your help to bring it to the next level! Contributions will go toward funding the following:

  • Programming budget to transform the Alpha Betty Soup ebook into an interactive learning application;
  • Engine, platform, and additional licensing costs;
  • Music and sound effects budget;
  • Marketing budget.

 



Aside from my eternal gratitude, there are lots of great perks that you will receive for pledging!
Check it out:

 

My name is Mellanie Bauslaugh and I live in London, Ontario, Canada with my husband, two children and muddy puppy. A baker, gardener, constant doodler and painter, I love all things creative and colourful.

I am a graphic designer, and currently co-run a game development company. I have also taught graphic and web design at my local community college for the past 15 years.

If you cannot pledge, you can certainly help in other ways!

story_txt:
I have been writing and drawing for as long as I can remember and it has always been a dream of mine to write and illustrate a children's book.
 



 
Alpha Betty Soup started as a series of drawings of my daughter, Marley. Being 5 years old (at the time), she was very interested in the letters of the alphabet and was beginning to learn to read, so an ABC book was a natural choice for me, as her mom.
 


I had lots of fun writing all of the silly, rhyming verses of the book and drawing the matching illustrations for each letter of the alphabet. I really enjoyed seeing the delight on my daughter's face as I developed the Betty character and took her on this giggly journey through the ABCs.
 
The book is now completed and available as an ebook on Kobo, Amazon and iTunes. But my true vision for Alpha Betty Soup has always been to turn it into an interactive mobile application with sound effects, read along capabilities, animations and music. But alas, in order to add these features, I need help from other talented geeks like myself.
 
So that brings us to my campaign.
 
 


Up until this point, my book has been completely self-funded.I do, however, need your help to bring it to the next level! Contributions will go toward funding the following:

Programming budget to transform the Alpha Betty Soup ebook into an interactive learning application;
Engine, platform, and additional licensing costs;
Music and sound effects budget;
Marketing budget.


 



Aside from my eternal gratitude, there are lots of great perks that you will receive for pledging!Check it out:


 



My name is Mellanie Bauslaugh and I live in London, Ontario, Canada with my husband, two children and muddy puppy. A baker, gardener, constant doodler and painter, I love all things creative and colourful.I am a graphic designer, and currently co-run a game development company. I have also taught graphic and web design at my local community college for the past 15 years.



If you cannot pledge, you can certainly help in other ways!Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Send this page link to your friends and colleagues or use the Indiegogo share tools on this site to help promote my campaign.
Every little bit counts. Cheers!

story:
The beginnings...
 
I have been working with nonprofits on a wide range of technology issues for almost twenty years. I still remember helping an organization put in its first network by pulling cable in the ceiling (I think the pants I ruined doing that might still be in my rag pile). I've been on nonprofit boards (including the board of NTEN, the Nonprofit Technology Network, and Aspiration.) I blogged on these topics for many years and I've seen software and hardware trends come and go, but ultimately, the same issues remain: Why use technology, anyway? How do we harness technology best to accomplish our mission? How do we navigate the bewildering set of options for everything from our network to social media to figure out what will work best?
 
The book...
 
This book, titled "Zen and the Art of Nonprofit Technolgy" aims to dig into these questions, bring out the most important factors, and provide concrete support and advice for decision-making,  but at a higher level than most resources. I won't tell you which CRM to pick, or even list the options, but I will tell you a lot about why you might or might not need one, what you can do with them, and how to go about making an informed choice based on your particular situation. I won't tell you whether to use Facebook, Twitter or Pinterest, or how make iOS or Android apps, but I will bring in resources to help you understand how to look at your constituents, and measure your impact. I will also place all of these new (and not so new) trends and technologies in context, so you can better understand the changing landscape, and when to commit resources, and when to wait. This book is not only about teaching you how to fish, but explaining why you should fish, and, further, when you should grow beans, or ranch cows, instead of fish.
 
I'll talk a bit about the history of technology, the use of hardware and software in nonprofits, the sometimes thorny relationships between vendors and organizations, and the political and philosophical conundrums inherent in this enterprise. The book will delve into the good old proprietary vs. open source debate, and will lay out some good, concrete answers to that debate that will help you make decisions. And, most importantly, I will explore sector-wide technology issues, and place much of this in a bigger picture context. 
 
I have written a tentative outline.
 
I am giving this book away in a gesture of generosity to the sector. The book will have a Creative Commons license, and released in paper and e-book formats. It will also be a living document, open to modification and discussion over time.
 
The work...
 
I've been hatching this book for more than a year. Since I make my living building websites for nonprofits, getting time to write this book has been a big challenge. $10,000 will buy about two months of my time to write. $3,000 will buy design services for the cover and website, and $2,000 will go for publicity. so this book can get in as many hands as possible.
 
There are some great perks! Check them out! There are paper copies, tweets, and even consulting hours!
 
If you can't contribute, I completely understand. It would be fabulous if you spread the word to your community and colleagues!

story:
Black Nazi- A short drama film

A young Black man who grew up in a life of privilege begins to question who he really is and the loyalty he has to the Aryan Brotherhood and his friends.

SYNOPSIS

“Black Nazi” is a story about identity and hate. This film follows a young Black Man (Brandon) that through his loyalty to his friends and the Arian brother hood has lost a sense of who he really is. What happens when his friends get him into trouble and he starts to question everything he thinks is true, can he make the right choice before there is no going back.

WHY HELP MAKE OUR FILM?

"Black Nazi" has a common theme that I feel will reach many people. Everyone has trouble with Identity & Hate at some point in their lives. After serving in the Middle East for over a year I was discharged from the military and decided to finish my degree in theater arts. After witnessing the destruction of what hate caused, I was told I suffered from Post traumatic stress disorder from being in combat, through the grace of God and my family I checked into a PTSD combat stress program at the VA hospital, living in the hospital for a year. During my down time I decided to express myself through writing short stories. Some were about my experiences in Iraq others were about my experiences in LA.

When I graduated from the program and went back out to the real world I experienced the racial tension between blacks, Hispanics, and Middle Eastern people. As similar as we were I came to find out we were so divided. I found it more alarming that most of my confrontations were with fellow black people. There are more black-on-black crimes than there are hate crimes, but when someone brings that up most blacks immediately get defensive. I did more research and found out there are more same race crimes than hate crimes. What about self-hate? Everything has a beginning so I wanted to tell a story of one individuals beginning. I took a little bit of my story from being the only African American in a predominantly white school and feeling different but hating the fact that I was different. This story is very brutal and graphic but has a strong message and hopefully it will force us as a society to take a look at ourselves.

I think this project effects everyone, hate doesn’t have a color, age, or gender it doesn’t matter if you’re rich or poor. Serving in Iraq I’ve seen firsthand the devastation of hate and there’s only one thing stronger than hate it’s love but if you don’t love yourself it’s difficult to feel anything but the opposite. I hope this film can bring attention to this spreading epidemic.

 

 

HOW CAN YOU GET INVOLVED?

This is your opportunity to become a part of something special! Here's how you can help: First of all please SHARE THIS PAGE with your friends, family, and co-workers! The more exposure the better chance we have at reaching our goal.

Please GIVE WHAT YOU CAN! Every dollar counts! We understand that times are tough, but this is your chance to help a talented group of people create a great short film!

HOW WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION BE USED?

The funds raised will be used for the entire cost of production. Here are a few examples but not limited to:

- Equipment (Cameras/lighting/sound)

- Set construction

- Travel expenses

- Film Festival Fees

- Location expenses

- Payment to the actors/actresses

- Payment to the production crew

- Marketing & advertising materials

- Legal services/license fees

- DVD/Promotional Production


MEET THE FILMMAKERS

Please take the time to head over to the UPDATES tab to meet our cast and crew! We've assembled a terrific group of filmmakers. Take the opportunity to get to know who it is you are helping reach their goal.

Thank you for your generous support & we'll see you at the movies!

-Sharieff Walters

Sharieff Walters Bio: Sharieff Walters is from San Jose California, and has been living in Los Angeles for the last nine years. Before moving to LA he was in the Marine Corps serving in Iraq. He has a degree in theater.

story:
Succe$$ and Failure

Expanding the Minds of Inner-City Youth One Book at a Time

A Sacred Journey of Success


Ever had a dream that you could not let go of? A bold longing that dared you to move beyond your fear to d.eper faith? I have...and I invite you to join me on this journey.

My name is Horace Dobson (aka Tony Dolison). I’m an entrepreneur from Detroit. I am an author of eight screenplays (you have probably already seen "The Substitute Postman”, if not, the trailer is below). I am a published author ("Love in the Shadows", "Nothing but the Truth", "Success and Failure", etc.). I also have invaluable experience from society having worked as a police officer, as a marks an in the Air Force, registered nurse, and as a business owner.

My new book is a thrilling, eye opening, biographical look at the heights of success and the depths of failure. This book traces my first entrepreneurial experience, to the heights of running an exotic car company that made almost 3 million dollars in less than 6 months only to take a plunge in 2008.  This book is motivational and will give its readers an honest look upon true success and true failure. It will help you to achieve your definition of success in life!

http://www.tonydolison.com/success.html

Your financial contibution will bring this story to life and put it into the hands of our youth, who struggle to find a direction! Lets expand the minds of our youth.  As Mr. Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. so eloquently put it; "A mind once expanded, can never go back to its original size".

                                                                                   

LETS TAKE BACK THE MINDS OF OUR YOUTH

 

A growing entitlement mentality has taken over our society as individuals ask themselves: “why should I work for it when I can get it for free?”. As this mentality is passed on to succeeding generations, it has an escalating snowball effect. In other words, “the more it grows, the more it grows.”

My goal is to influence our youth to reject this entitlement mentality and embrace a healthier state of mind that innovates them and helps them create opportunity for themselves and others.

We have all been told by others at some point that we have personal limitations. For example, as an actor, I was told that I was too tall and too big to be the leading star of a movie. Instead of being discouraged, I decided to make my own movie where I was the leading star. My goal is to provide an option...to empower inner city youth to reach for the stars and not wait around for a hand out. To be the young man, or woman, who can grow as a person and later help others in a similar manner. Provide another type of snowball effect...a healthy one!

I need YOUR help to raise a minimum of $11,000 to cover project expenses (travel  costs, copy/editing, printing, distribution, etc.)

What’s in it For You?

  • Satisfaction in being an active part of a positive change in society inspriring self-sufficiency and creating healthy youths. 
  • Depending on donation amount, unique gifts for the donor.
  • Potential to be part of other creative processes (e.g., my new movie, projects, charity, etc.).
  • Claim rewards at the right side of your screen.

My biography can be found at http://www.horacedobson.com

Succe$$ and Failure is my most ambitious project to date. I call it a project with purpose as my previous projects were mostly for entertainment and less altruistic motives. This project is for a greater purpose...its intention is empowerment leading to change in our community!

Where Will the Money Go?

 

  • Professional copy/editing services for a publication-ready final manuscript

  • Graphic design

  • Printing and production of limited edition book prototypes

  • Fees collected by IndieGogo (@4%) 

  • Production, processing and postage for supporter rewards and the 1000 books

Each additional $10,000 raised will allow the campaign to print and give out an additional 1000 books! 

Can't donate but want to help? Make some noise! Tweet, blogging, email, and Facebook are all wonderful ways to tell others about this campaign. Call your buddies to ask them to invest! And last, but not least, send up some affirming prayers – your positive energy will be a wonderful contribution!

Let’s Raise $11K in 35 days!!!

I’m counting on you to make The Succe$$ and Failure project a resounding success!

Love and Blessings,

Horace Dobson

Why IndieGogo Before Publishing?

FAQs

1. What is IndieGogo and how does this thing work? IndieGogo is one of the world’s largest crowdfunding websites, generating millions of projects in over 160 countries. IndieGogo charges 4% for successful projects and 9% for projects that don’t meet fundraising goals. Founded in 2008, the company has appeared on Bloomberg, Oprah, Today, and the BBC, as well as in the Wall Street Journal and The New York Times. Learn more here.

2. How do I donate? Click the “CONTRIBUTE NOW” button on the right hand side of
the page and follow the prompts. (FYI, your credit card information is protected and is never saved by Indiegogo]. Enter an email address where you would like to receive your contribution receipt. Once my IndieGogo campaign ends in December 17, 2013, I will request your address and to follow-up on any additional reward related matters.

3. What happens to the funds if you don’t reach your fundraising goal? This is a two-tiered fundraising campaign. If I don’t reach the first goal of ($11K) then I may not be able to complete some of the items outlined above – or donate the PLANNED number of books and it will inhibit my ability to reach out to speak to Inner-City youth across the country.

4. What if I can’t give right now? All your support and encouragement is so valued. Creative suggestions are welcome. And you can get your friends to pledge. Shout it out from the hills!!! If you’ve got even $5 that helps boost our backer numbers as much as someone giving $500 or $5,000.

5. Is shipping and handling covered for the rewards? S&H is including for all items being shipped within the U.S. International shipping costs will depend on the country where rewards will be shipped. Please allow for additional time for international delivery.

Like the Succe$$ and Failure project on Facebook: 

Other ways you can help........For every box of gourmet healthy coffee we sell, between now and the first of the year, we will DONATE one book to an inner city youth. Click website below to find out more info on that.
