Whether it’s learning how to play guitar, or how to handle your first classroom as a teacher, nothing beats finding the right tool to help you succeed. We all know this tool, too—the one that enables the"aha!" moment—and instantly connects with you, leaving you feeling empowered.
However, searching for the right book can often feel like a herculean task. We've been there, trying to find the right book to use with our students or just on our own. That’s why we created Low Down Publishing—to develop books specifically for music teachers and self-guided learners—and eliminate the stressful process of finding the right resource. We make the "aha!" moment a core part of your learning experience.
 

Here’s the truth—books have a seemingly impossible job.
 
Imagine having to create a resource that captures the interest of a diverse audience and teaches them a skill in detail, yet you don't know exactly who will be using it. You may never meet your reader face to face or understand what their individual needs are. Further, once it leaves your hands, you can’t control how they use or interpret it. No wonder it can be so hard to find the right book that connects with you!
 
It doesn’t have to be, though.
 
Look—we understand that no book is a catch-all and no book can ever replace a great teacher. However, we recognize that great teachers and students need great resources; books and tools that are:

Up-to-date with current musical trends and issues
Targeted to produce specific learning outcomes
Broad enough to reach students with diverse interests, yet
Helpful to teachers with wide-ranging teaching experiences

 
Everything we produce is built on research findings. Our resources provide expert opinions and leave room for teachers and students to draw their own conclusions and decide how to best apply them. Our resources help to eliminate the question, "Will this resource work for me?"
 
Our Story
The publishing bug hit Danny in 2013 while teaching at SUNY Oswego. After studying available bass resources, and unable to find the exact right book to fit his bass students’ needs, he wrote The Low Down Vol. 1—a teaching sequence for walking bass lines, targeted directly at his students. Inspired by the results in his students and positive feedback from the bass community, Danny continued in 2016 with The Low Down Vol. 2.
(Creating DIY books can feel like an insane task, especially without many author resources available to musicians. This was the major impetus for us offering author services—but more on that later).

Danny's first three publications
 
Danny's curiosities led him back to the Eastman School of Music in 2016, where he also met Erik Piazza, John Mills, and Michael Sherman. Danny's research focus and master’s thesis was on jazz double bass pedagogy, which helped form the basis of Topics in Jazz Bass (2018). Numerous discussions amongst the founders about teaching, research, and the need for more resources ultimately formed the foundation of LDP.
 

Okay, so technically Danny’s first book was written when he was 7, not 24… but his mom and dad paid for the only available copy. It was a low budget production (<$10) and he was forced to do his own illustrative work.
 
Our 2020 Catalog
These books represent research of their respective fields and are written by some of the best musicians and educators today.  [Titles are subject to change; content will not change]
The Art of Combining Chords and Melodies on Guitar by Bob Sneider (Guitarist, Professor at Eastman School of Music). Bob presents his innovative approach to playing chord melodies on guitar in solo and trio settings, complete with supplemental audio. 
A Practical Rudimental Approach to Drumming Vol. 1 By Carmen Intorre Jr (Drummer for the Pat Martino Trio). Carmen's book will help beginning percussion students learn the rudiments and how to musically apply them to the drumset.
Jazz Warmups for All Instrumentalists by Doug Stone (Saxophonist, Professor of Jazz at Louisiana State University). Doug's jazz warmup helps all instrumentalists, regardless of experience, develop vocabulary as a part of their daily practice routine.
Topics in Jazz Bass Vol. 2: Soloing by Danny Ziemann. This book will serve bassists looking to improve their soloing practice. Each chapter serves as a standalone topic, offering many practice techniques bassists can incorporate to develop soloing vocabulary. Many exercises include embedded ear training, perfect for bassists of all experience levels.
Practical Advice for Reflective Music Teachers by John Mills, Erik Piazza, and Danny Ziemann. This resource is targeted at pre-service and beginning music teachers, using scenarios and vignettes to examine some of the common beliefs or questions teachers might have in their careers.
 
Rewards
In addition to our 2020 catalog, we're providing perks including: skype lessons, internet masterclasses, compositions named after you, special videos, and book dedications. These perks are only available through our campaign. If your reward includes one or more of our titles, please email info@lowdownpublishing.com with your choice!

Note: All rewards have an estimated delivery date of "by December 2020", though our projected timeline for the books is mid-2020. 
Budget & Timeline
Making a book is expensive, let alone five!  The bulk of our operating costs are design-related. Compelling artwork and proper typesetting ensure that you will have the best engagement with the book. Then, of course, there’s the cost of printing, print setup fees, ISBNs, copyrights, online hosting for our supplemental material, shipping costs, and revisions.
All books are currently being written and in various editing stages. We have our latest deadline as December 2020, though we aim to have everything done much earlier than that!
 

Who We Are
LDP is a four-person team, led by Danny Ziemann, with combined decades of teaching experience and professional performing experience, and mentorship by the NextCorps business incubator.

 
Risks & Challenges
Meeting deadlines while managing the production of multiple books can be difficult, and of course, presents the biggest risk. However, the founders' publishing experience helps to mitigate risk and keep a strict production deadline. Each author follows a schedule, in collaboration with the founders, to help meet projected deadlines.

Thank you for bringing our campaign to great success!
We know not everyone can donate. However, you can still be a HUGE help to us by:

Sharing our campaign through social media, and
Helping us to create some buzz and excitement!

Please use the Indiegogo tools at the bottom of the page to share our project.

story:
(The Editors, pre-prom. 1996)

WHISKEYPAPER:

  • WhiskeyPaper is an online literary magazine founded in 2012 and edited by Leesa Cross-Smith (author of Every Kiss A War, Mojave River Press, 2014) and Loran Smith. WhiskeyPaper publishes one new story every Sunday, 52 new stories a year. SOON, we want to hand-make chapbooks in our house, open the kitchen door and label envelopes on our back deck so we can send little paper treats to your front porch. 

  • In addition to being a writer, Leesa Cross-Smith has also edited for other literary magazines like SmokeLong Quarterly, Hobart and Mojave River Review. She won Editor's Choice in the Raymond Carver Short Story Award and was shortlisted for writing awards like the Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction and the Iowa Short Fiction Award. Her work has been published in places likeThe Rumpus, Carve Magazine, Little Fiction, Word Riot, NANO Fiction, Monkeybicycle, Juked, Midwestern Gothic and Gigantic Sequins, among many others. 

  • Together, Editor Leesa Cross-Smith & WhiskeyPaper had NINE mentions on the 2014 Wigleaf Top 50 & Longlist which highlights the best short fiction online.

  • With your help, WhiskeyPaper  will be able to put out @ least two new chapbooks a year, beginning in 2015, as well as some anthologies. Any and all money over our goal will go towards our future-future dreams (hinging on funding/opportunities) like longer works of fiction (novellas, novels, full-length short story collections) all under WhiskeyPaper Press. A glass of WhiskeyPaper, a fifth of WhiskeyPaper, a barrel of WhiskeyPaper...all of us, drinking words.

  • So far, WhiskeyPaper has published stories from both brand-new/emerging writers and well-established book award winning writers about stuff like: antlers, baseball, chupacabra, divorce, Elvis, funeral crowds, God, homelessness, ice cream trucks, Jameson, Kentucky, leaky rowboat hearts, milk, NBA Jam, online dating, proof, quitting, running away, staying home, tigers, unicorns, vandalism, weed, your hands.

  • We will be open for submissions and would love to publish minimalist chapbooks/anthologies about stuff like: Americana, baseball, cowboys & country music, diners, elk, Felicity, Gilmore Girls, hippies, island life, Jesus, kissing & Kings of Leon, losing things (keys? virginity?), motorcycle clubs, Nintendo, obsession, pizza, Queen, road trip snacks, sneaking out & sk8boarding, Twin Peaks, UFOs (?), veggie gardens, whiskey, x-large gas station slushies, yacht rock. 


WHAT SOME OTHER PEOPLE HAVE TO SAY ABOUT WHISKEYPAPER & ITS EDITOR:

"If you could hold WhiskeyPaper in your hands, it would be dog-eared and finger-worn, coffee-stained and scented with bourbon."_Refe Tuma, author of WHAT THE DINOSAURS DID LAST NIGHT (Little, Brown 2014) and short fiction at Necessary Fiction, Bartleby Snopes, Literary Orphans, and elsewhere.

"A fresh-faced, rising star of the lit world, WhiskeyPaper consistently publishes the strongest, most beautiful work out there. Huge admiration & love for this journal!"_Kathy Fish, author of Wild Life and Together We Can Bury It

"With every issue, WhiskeyPaper reminds me that I need to see the rest of the United States before I die. All of it."_Erin Fitzgerald, Series Editor 2014 Wigleaf 50 and Staff Editor, Smokelong Quarterly

"WhiskeyPaper is hearing your favorite song come on the jukebox and having your heart break all over again. It’s Saturday night dancing, drinking, and heartache served in a shot glass with your Sunday brunch. It’s a shortcut to falling in love."_Georgia Bellas, writer, artist, and creator of the Internet radio show “Mr. Bear’s Violet Hour Saloon”

"WhiskeyPaper publishes stories that are soaked in summer nights. They are stories full of love and heartbreak, lightness and tragedy, whiskey and baseball. Read them as the sun goes down, drink in your hand, wind at your back."_Troy Palmer, managing editor at Little Fiction/Big Truths, proud WhiskeyPaper author

(re: EVERY KISS A WAR ) "Leesa Cross-Smith is a consummate storyteller who uses her formidable talents to tell the oft-overlooked stories of people living in that great swath of place between the left and right coasts. She offers thrilling turns of phrase like, “His mouth tasted like thousand-page Russian novels I’d never read,” or “let your smeary mouth be his question mark.” Where she is most stunning is in the endings of each of the 27 stories in Every Kiss a War, creating crisp, evocative moments that will linger long after you’ve read this book’s very last word.”_Roxane Gay, author of An Untamed State and Bad Feminist.


WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET:

  • We want to raise @ least $2500! The money will go towards continuing the minimalist, visually-pleasing ad-free website so you can keep reading/submitting stories for free, an awesome high-quality printer so we can make the chapbooks in-house with high-quality ink and paper that will last and stay beautiful, as well as all of the supplies that go with (PO Box, software, paper, envelopes, toner...). We also want to provide our authors/chapbooks with proper ISBN numbers and barcodes so they can feel like they are "real" books because to us, chapbooks are real books. And providing them with ISBN numbers/barcodes makes tracking things easier for us/the authors/indie bookstores.

  • PERKS! We have coming-soon hand-numbered chapbooks and the option to be included in our coming-soon WhiskeyPaper Friends section of our website where your name/personal website can be listed so we can shout out how much we love you, as well as promote your stuff! On the upper tier levels, we have really cute WhiskeyPaper koozies for your cold cans and boats and bonfires and signed copies of Every Kiss a War! (Perks only available for shipping to US/CANADA.)

  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we still love you and thank you and promise to use the money responsibly and put out @ least one chapbook anyway, forthcoming Spring 2015. We have already selected our first author/chapbook and will be announcing that soon! We also have a CRUSH-themed anthology and a BASEBALL-themed anthology in the baby-early phases. What we're saying is: Can't stop, won't stop.


    A FIFTH OF WHISKEYPAPER PRESS: CHAPBOOKS/ANTHOLOGIES. OUR FUTURE.

    • We ain't running a long con! This isn't about moneymaking. This is about artmaking. This is about bookmaking. There is so much good stuff out there! So many writers waiting in the wings, taking their rightful place center stage, just waiting for a small press to take a chance on them and we want to! Of course the more money we make the more we can do! More money equals more chapbooks/more opportunities/more authors/more good stuff! We would love to one day be in a position to put together Best of WhiskeyPaper anthologies on a regular basis and share some cash-money love with our chapbook authors/contributors.

    • WhiskeyPaper has been around for 2+ years and wants to be around for a looong time. We're in this all the way. We don't half-ace things and we won't start now.

    • Even if we do not reach our goal, we're not giving up! We have ideas for anthologies and reading events and we'll keep on keeping on. Lord willing and the creek don't rise, WhiskeyPaper is in it to win it. *cue Drake's "Started From the Bottom"*


      OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

      • Even if you can't donate,  prettyplease pass the word along!

      • Read WhiskeyPaper! Share the stories you love! (We believe there's a little something for everyone in our archives.) And tell your friends about us please! Also submit a story of your own when we are open to submissions because we'd love to read it! Also, support local art/indie bookstores in your area! It matters and you matter. Your heart, your words, your art, it matters. The world needs you!

      • Follow WhiskeyPaper on Twitter, Tumblr & Facebook for new stories & updates!

      • Use the Indiegogo share tools to do the dang thang!

      Hit up whiskeypaper AT gmail DOT com if you have any questions! WE LOVE YOU! THANK YOU SO MUCH! We love you like ex oh.

story:
The God Book

Rabbi Jack Books is known for taking complex ideas and making them accessible in down-to-earth language. Having already addressed the books of the Prophets and the Writings (in The Nach Yomi Companion), the weekly Torah portion (in The Shnayim Mikra Companion), the 613 commandments (in The Taryag Companion) and the laws of personal conduct (in The Tzniyus Book), Rabbi Jack is ready to tackle the world of Jewish philosophy.

The God Book, based upon the Rambam's Moreh Nevuchim (The Guide for the Perplexed), will collect articles currently running on OU Torah under the title "The God Papers," plus other material of interest.

The God Book is designed to introduce readers to authentic - and often surprising! - ideas of the nature of God. Also covered in this volume: Divine providence, the creation of the world, angels, prophecy, and more.

The God Book will be accessible to beginners but it will also be appreciated by those with more thorough Jewish educations, as the average school's curriculum doesn't spend much time on the nature of God and other matters of metaphysics.

story:
Who are we and what do we do?


  • Humanities First was launched in response to the need within the humanities for affordable editorial support and feedback. Many scholars have had trouble placing their manuscripts with presses or journals simply because of inaccessible prose and badly edited writing. This should never happen. At Humanities First, we can help you. We have the time, resources and expertise to help shape your book or article into the kind of clear and polished work that is prized by academic publishers.
  • Developmental editing is a multi-stage editorial process that ensures clarity of expression and consistency of ideas. The final outcome of developmental review is a polished and accessible document that is legible to a wide readership.
  • As a nonprofit organization, Humanities First is able to provide top-notch content analysis and copy editing at a reasonable cost. Scholars spend countless hours on research and time is valuable. Editorial guidance is a key factor in ensuring that  research is developed and polished into a publication-ready manuscript.

What We Need & What You Get

But we need your help:

  • To keep our costs low and to make sure those who most benefit from this service, we are launching a service whereby senior scholars can help to create a reserve of funds to help provide graduate students and contingent faculty with subsidized or free developmental editing services.
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal, the money goes towards helping any person in need of editing. This money is earmarked to help contingent faculty, graduate students and people with disabilities and anyone who doesn't have access to institutional funds to help defray the costs of developmental editing.

The Impact

Humanities First is dedicated to:

  • Making editing accessible to everyone who needs it. This campaign specifically helps graduate students and contingent faculty and those with low or no institutional funds.
  • Our clients have successfully filed dissertations, have published  in peer-reviewed journals included ALH, MELUS,  and a published books with major presses including The University of Minnesota Press, Temple University Press.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help by getting the word out:

  • Let people know about our campaign.
  • Please share this with your friends and colleagues!
  • And remember, every little bit helps. If we work as a community, we can collectively harness our resources to our colleagues and serve as good mentors.
  • And best of all, all of your donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE!
